review_title: Not your average start-up, and that's a good thing.
pros:
I have worked at Opendoor (DFW market) for nearly a year, and it's my best working experience to date. This is my third start-up, and by far the most promising.

Yes, we have the ping-pong table. Yes, we have the cold brew on tap. And yes, the perks are unbelievable. But that's not just it....

We also have the self-motivators, entrepreneurs, and business minds growing this into a powerhouse empire. We are actively putting structure, policies, and procedures in place — and working out the bugs that don't work. We pack a year in 3 months, and I am blown away by the company and each employee's personal growth.

What keeps me? Easy — the freedom and limitless potential. You make your future here. It sounds corny, but it's a liberating grind, and we choose it each day. Rarely do I hear the word "no", and I have had the freedom to bring culture and operations ideas to life. Essentially, you decide how far you get to go here. I feel empowered by my coworkers and by C-level execs to conquer my goals and be my best, most innovative self.

Plus, I am working with some of the most futuristic, innovative, creative, brilliant people of my lifetime. I feel inspired each day to be better, do better, produce better.
cons: It is still a start-up. Like most, we are breathless every Friday afternoon from an action-packed grind. (But we have an in-office happy hour, so it isn't a terrible way to finish off the week.) I believe it's not a permanent status — just an effect of growing.

pros: Everyone is extremely positive and excited to be there, and that’s contagious. I’ve never known such a smart, capable group of people.
cons:
Work-life balance isn’t a thing. People aren’t taking vacations despite “unlimited PTO” and are often working outside normal hours and on days off. Boundary setting is difficult but necessary.

Another problem I’m seeing is the crazy spending. Free lunch every day and bad travel planning are going to help the long term financial health of the company.
advice_to_mgmt: Bring back the wellness perks and make sure work-life balance is real unless you want heavy turnover and burnouts. Watch the discretionary spending though.

pros:
Smart and Humble People
The first thing the recruiter told me when I asked about what Opendoor was like was this, "everyone is really smart and works really hard." She couldn't have been more right. I'd add on there that everyone is really smart and incredibly humble and interested in new ideas and expertise.

Great Mission
What we're doing is incredibly challenging and amazingly focused on the mission of empowering people to move. People are focused and passionate about making the home buying and selling process much easier.

Nimble
People are not afraid to make mistakes and be nimble, which is mission critical in a company at this stage.

Data Driven
We're a company founded on data, and while at times the data can be overwhelming, using data to support decisions and ideas is critical.

Implementation of Feedback
Feedback is encouraged, and better than that, embraced. For example, folks have been asking for more training and development. The Head of People took that to heart and was pretty quick to open up the role, to which I as lucky enough to be the right fit to lead our Learning & Development efforts.
cons:
Work/life Balance
This varies by team and by office. In some cases it's quite challenging. There is a personal component that can come into play and cause some of this imbalance. That said, if you set boundaries, they are respected and appreciated.

Communication and Change Management
A bit of this is to be expected for the stage of the company. What worked for communication and pushing change with 100 employees doesn't work as well as you have more than 500. Leaders are certainly moving in the right direction with how they're managing any change (which loads of change is to be expected in a late stage start up). Communication is a bit challenging as the org structure is complex and it's not always clear who to communicate to about what.
advice_to_mgmt:
1) Celebrate examples of work/life balance - there can be a tendency to celebrate heroic efforts, which can inadvertently encourage other heroic efforts of folks working on their days off, while on vacation, etc.

2) Add people representation to company values - the values are product and customer focused and believe we'd benefit from a company value that highlights/promotes employee communication, teamwork, etc.

3) Continue working on job families and the process for internal transfers - people are hungry for career pathing and it can be unclear when people are plugged into roles and others would have liked to have given an opportunity for the role. Progress has been made already in the time I've been here, continue on this path.

review_title: Difficult for me to say this but the work environment has declined
pros: Without question I have never worked with a more intelligent, more driven group of people. The concept behind the business is solid, and I honestly believe this can (and should) shake up the entire industry. The company encourages employees to take risks and act with a sense of ownership. The overall company culture is very progressive and inclusive of people from all walks of life. The CEO is a true leader and well respected.
cons: An unfortunate divide has been emerging between "upper level" management in San Francisco HQ and the actual "on the ground" operations in the local markets. Residential real estate is an intense business - a common adage is that a home is the single biggest purchase or sale most people will ever make. While the traditional process can definitely be streamlined it cannot and should not be cut to "bare bones" service by stretching the operations teams far, far beyond capacity. The company seems to suddenly be comfortable offering a trimmed down, discounted level of service in exchange for tremendous investment in all sorts of typical Silicon Valley "moonshot" type ideas. There seem to be entire teams working on white board discussing theoretical businesses that might be a possibility in 2023. But we're not making it that far if the current approach continues. Impressive growth only matters if we're delivering a half decent product. Basically, there's an imbalance between what seem to be high-level Silicon Valley dreamers with impressive degrees, and people actually doing the real work.
advice_to_mgmt:
This company was built upon a positive, inclusive mindset where all employees were valued for their own unique contributions. You're losing this, and we're drifting into tech bro land. The overall demeanor expressed by some of the HQ types when they travel to local markets is a little gross and elitist and needs to be checked. You have people in those markets working 12+ hour days just about every day - be respectful and appreciative, not distant and oddly patronizing. Or, you know, just don't visit at all. Invest more in your local teams, and significantly less in company travel for a select few (the company travel at this company is weird, I've never seen anything like it and I've worked in a number of corporate settings and industries).

Best of luck. I really do think this place can change the industry in a very positive way. Just remember that as with all real estate, it starts at the local level.

review_title: A Company That Doesn’t Have Your Back
pros:
- I had the privilege of working with some of the most intelligent and hard working individuals to ever come across professionally. Some extremely innovative persons, who are and were willing to making Opendoor into the the thriving company I ONCE believed it could have been. Unfortunately that changed in a matter of days and following some pretty inhumane behavior.

- Initially perks started out great; uber, growth, health & wellness - this was essentially to recruit as many people as possible but once the seats were filled, and teams were established, all the perks went out the window.
cons:
- Very self centered environment - if you’re not based or flown out from the SF office, with some prestige college on your resume, you really don’t matter and that was felt across multiple teams.

- There was no professional growth, at all - no real road map for individuals within the company, very stagnant.

- Every man for themselves type vibe & was extremely hard to work in teams on projects because essentially your idea had to be the best and everyone else sucked.

- You let an entire team go, along with their management, and they only explanation that was given was, “We’re going in a different direction for 2018” - which from what I hear, hasn’t been going too well and it’s even more of a shiz show more than ever.

- Upper management does not have your back! At. All. When concerns were brought to higher up, I was told, “Don’t worry about it, you’re fine - we will cross that bridge when we get there.” Two days later, an entire team that was over performing, was let go for no logical explanation. How about you hold your operations team accountable for having such “low & attainable” goal numbers, that were continuously met! Biggest stab in the back by far.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Think about your customers! Stop trying to automate everything & outsource. It clearly didn’t work when you slashed the whole Sales team, and appointments were being self schedule by customers, who then never received calls.

- Hire management that have the skills AND background to develop your teams collectively and individually.

- Don’t continue to screw over your employees who put in their blood, sweat, and tears to make your product great.

- Also, next time before you so easily dispose of an entire team, have the decency to at least wait a couple days before making everyone else post about current job openings that those previous employees were more than capable of doing & would have done so happily. It wouldn’t have been hard to place them elsewhere in the company.

Focus on buying and selling real estate, building positive customer reviews, and utilizing the phenomenal talent right in front of you... your market employees!
If you truly want " what's best for Opendoor, you would put Mark Won and Kerry Melcher in charge, Make David Barens head of Sales and fire all these higher up SF dimwits.

pros:
- Best people I've ever worked with - everyone is incredibly smart, ambitious and high character. I'm lucky to be able to call many of my co-workers close friends.

- Massive opportunity in front of us: residential real estate is a $25 trillion (yes, with a T) asset class and the customer experience is largely unchanged in decades. No other company out there has the ambitions, capabilities and access to capital needed to redefine such a large, complex and historically change-resistant industry.

- Strong customer-centric values from leadership on down. You can't build a valuable consumer brand without a maniac focus on delivering a great customer experience every day and these values are built into our DNA.

- Really interesting problems to work on. It's never easy, but every day we get to work on some of the most interesting problems out there.
cons:
Redefining the real estate industry isn't easy work. Our business is incredibly complex and requires operational excellence across a wide range of surface areas:

- customer experience (both via software and real-world touch points)
- home pricing algorithms
- risk management
- real estate operations (keeping hundreds - soon thousands - of homes across the country clean, secure, accessible and it great condition isn't easy)
- finance (capital markets, fp&a, accounting)
- bizdev / partnerships

Unlike many companies that can focus on doing one or two things well each quarter, we need to consistently execute and a high level of excellence across all of these functional units every day. It can be tiring sometimes.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to keep the bar high while hiring aggressively. Keep pushing teams to execute against ambitious roadmaps with the urgency required to win the space.

review_title: Amazing people that challenges you to go beyond what you think you can accomplish
pros: It is a cliche to say that the people at Opendoor are forward thinkers, however, they truly are. From the CEO, Eric Wu all the way down to the Workplace staff, everyone has great ideas on how to make Opendoor an enjoyable and fulfilling professional experience. One of Opendoor's core values is #actfromownership; there's a lot of support within the teams to allow individuals to take on different ideas and it's exciting. Having a $1500 educational stipend is really nice to help each person grow professional and prepare for potential new roles that have/are developing, so there's space to grow within. Overall the work environment is pretty standard for a start-up (i.e. open environment, afterhour group hang-outs, cater lunch, snacks and amusement games to help relive stress during work hours).
cons: There's no official road map for employees to grow professionally within Opendoor even though the company has the educational stipend and we can bring up growth through 1:1 meetings, however, It would be great if there was a plan built together so that each person that wants to stay the next 5, 10, or even 50 years can if we continue to put in the time and work on building this muscle. Having some of our perks (allowance for ride shares, headphones) and minimizing the ability for team gatherings hurts, it still does not out-weight the amazing people, the experience and joy of working at Opendoor.
advice_to_mgmt: Being able to have company meetings regularly at each market is a great boost of moral - it's hard to feel connected between offices as we are all so far away and rarely interact. Everyone who is here has and still is sacrificing personal, social, or financial benefits because we believe in what we're doing, the entire leadership from Eric to our local city leaders, I hope that it doesn't get lost as we are growing so quickly with mountain size goals that really stretches everyone thin at times.

review_title: Tl;dr - great people building a company for the right reasons
pros:
Just a few of the reasons that make me proud to work at Opendoor!

-The mission/impact: The classic startup trope applies here, residential real estate IS broken and Opendoor has a genuine desire to fix it. This makes it easy to come in to work every morning
-The caliber of the people: I left one of the "best places to work" by any relevant list and was surprised to see no drop in the quality of talent
-"Living" the company values: Customer-centricity and empowering others aren't just buzzwords for team members
-Perks: While perks should be far from first reason to join a company, being able to get a car home after hours, snacks, the fitness stipend, and other bonuses are definitely appreciated and helpful
cons:
No red flags, but every company has areas they can improve

-Implicit hours expectation: Hours can be a challenge when there is so much work to do. There thankfully is no explicit face time culture but finding the work/life balance that works for the individual can be tough
-Feedback and advancement: When the company moves so quickly it can be tough to know what the job could look like in two years or what the expectations for performance are
-Analyze vs. Act balance: With so many smart people at Opendoor problems can sometimes be analyzed to the N-th +1 degree when a decision should have already been made, we're quickly getting better at this
advice_to_mgmt: Continue relentlessly optimizing the experience of your customers and your employees, the rest will take care of itself!

pros:
I can only speak for the SF HQ, but here they are:

- Opendoor operates from a place of transparency. I feel well connected to other parts of the business that I don't work with on a regular basis. Company All-Hands do a great job of engaging employees and revealing any problems/updates of the company.
- High-growth but not crazy. For only being 2.5 yrs old, Opendoor has grown quite a lot. But our growth goals aren't crazy, as it's trying to avoid the pitfalls of other start-ups with crazy, unstructured growth.
- People. Everyone I've met has been smart, engaging, and welcoming.
- The perks and benefits! I know this shouldn't be such a huge deal, but they're pretty great! Unlimited PTO (that people actually use), daily catered meals, Uber credits, annual growth stipend, monthly gym stipend, etc.
cons:
Not much to say here.
- Office space. It's getting a bit cramped in 116 New Montgomery. We have plans to expand our office but for the moment it's really packed. Food runs out pretty quickly if you're not fast!
- Hours. In true start-up fashion, working hours are fairly flexible but at times overwhelming. It depends on your team and the individual, but it's not uncommon for me to get Slack messages and emails late at night or over the weekend. There's some pressure to stay later nights, but this is definitely up to the individual.
- Information overload. Opendoor teams use a TON of different tools (slack, email, Quip, Dropbox Paper, Google Docs, etc.). I think it'll be much easier moving forward to standardize where information is coming from and how we use these tools.
advice_to_mgmt: Not much I can think of, it's been great!

review_title: Great People. Great Product. Great Work Environment.
pros:
People: Opendoor's hiring bar is very high, which has resulted in a team of some of the brightest yet humble and collaborative minds across a number of disciplines
Product: The company has tremendous product-market fit. High NPS scores in concert with rapid volume growth demonstrate both the value and need for Opendoor's service.
Responsibility: Opendoor actively promotes its core value of 'Acting From Ownership,' and each team member is entrusted with being the DRI for several work streams.
cons: Hours: Depends on the team / individual, but hours / expected time being 'online' can be more strenuous

pros:
-Transparency: Everything from the top down is shared and all employees are 'in the know' at all times.

-Culture: Opendoor has an incredibly contagious culture. There is a strong sense of camaraderie across all departments in all markets and you genuinely feel like you are part of one GIANT team.

-Technology: It really is a tech company doing real estate which means the utilization of leading edge tech is phenomenal.

-Flexibility: The company as a whole is flexible. They are able to identify problems and implement solutions at the drop of a hat. Flexibility also stretches across work/life balance which is hard to find.

-Fun: Every day is fueled by hard work and dedication to achieving the greater goal of changing the real estate game, but Opendoor never forgets to break up the hard work with a little fun and encourages employees to make the most of each day.

-Appreciation: I, personally, have never worked for a company that shows so much appreciation to all of their employees. There is constant recognition for doing good work and sharing great ideas. Morale stays high because of the wonderful job they do making sure everyone feels appreciated.
cons: There aren't many, if any, cons to working for Opendoor, thus far.
advice_to_mgmt: Protect the culture. As the company grows and more official policies and procedures are put in place, don't abandon the "start-up" stye culture that has made Opendoor so great. Continue to foster the sharing of ideas and allow everyone to continue to work from first principals and feel like they are a valuable piece of the puzzle.

review_title: A transformational company with a path to victory
pros:
Opendoor is a swinging for the fences kind of company with a team of truly incredible people going after a gigantic opportunity. The company is building and growing so quickly that the rate at a which the team is learning is super fast, which makes for a dynamic work environment because the challenges you are tackling shift week to week.

The people are a remarkable combination of very smart without a ton of ego and everyone seems oriented towards building long-term value for the customer as opposed to short-term tactics to hit the numbers. Most startups say they value transparency and honesty but Opendoor actually does, both internally within the team and externally with customers.

Everyone at the company works very hard but the company is flexible about letting people work from home and employees are encouraged take time off, which is refreshing in comparison to the many companies who say they have these policies but no one feels comfortable using them.
cons: None really. Like any fast-growing startup, there are natural growing pains that the company goes through particular as we continue to onboard new people, teams expand and communication channels change.
advice_to_mgmt: Remain laser-focused on building value for customers and the long-term. Opendoor has an opportunity to be a truly transformational business that quite literally changes people's lives. Keep the bar for hiring high as we scale and continue investing in the culture because that's how we will win.

review_title: Lots of opportunity to learn and work with smart, enthusiastic people
pros:
There is so much to explore and be done across all projects and teams. Between scaling and the sheer complexity of the problems their tackling - you will never be bored.

The team also has a wide range of backgrounds, with some many who have a more laid back attitude than most start-ups this size. Not sure if it's because all the founders have been at various companies and jobs before - but it's a nice stable change from other startups I've worked at.

And everyone is so passionate and hard working - it makes you super inspired to get up every day to go to work.
cons: It's a growing start up so there's always more to do than people to do it. If 9-5 is your jam, not sure this is the place - thought they are pretty flexible with letting folks do their work when and where they need to (there are a surprising number of parents here).
advice_to_mgmt: Take a little more time to relax with the team. All your hard work is paying off and we'd love to make sure you enjoy this moment in time.
